thread.title_full: Sean Spicer has a serious bone to pick with Dippin’ Dots | New York Post

author: Lia Eustachewich
title: Sean Spicer has a serious bone to pick with Dippin’ Dots
text:
It’s not just the press – Sean Spicer also has a beef with Dippin’ Dots.
The new White House press secretary has been dishing out ice-cold insults against the tiny frozen balls of ice cream for years on Twitter.
Spicer began railing against the so-called “Ice Cream of the Future” in April 2010, when he tweeted , “Dippin dots is NOT the ice cream of the future.”
A year later, he reiterated his frosty observation : “I think I have said this before but Dippin Dots are notthe [sic] ice cream of the future.”
President Donald Trump’s flak then followed up two months later , tweeting a Wall Street Journal story about Dippin’ Dots filing for bankruptcy.
Spicer got one last dig in in 2015 and roped the Washington Nationals baseball team into his dairy beef.
“If Dippin Dots was truly the ice cream of the future they would not have run out of vanilla,” he groused .
No word on what Dippin’ Dots – the kid-approved snack made up of flash-frozen ice cream balls – did to deserve Spicer’s Twitter tongue-lashing.
But in a tongue-in-cheek response on its website Monday , Scott Fischer, the CEO of the Kentucky-based ice-cream company, said Spicer’s dessert debacle was a “serious matter.”
“Running out of your favorite flavor can feel like a national emergency!” Fischer said. “We’ve seen your tweets and would like to be friends rather than foes. After all, we believe in connecting the dots.”
He then tossed out a sweet offer — hosting an ice-cream social at the White House for Spicer and the press corps.
“What do you say? We’ll make sure there’s plenty of all your favorite flavors,” Fischer said.
A Dippin’ Dots spokeswoman said it has yet to hear back from the White House and Spicer.
She also said the brand no longer dubs itself “Ice Cream of the Future” but now uses the slogan “Taste the Fun.”
